ENV100H1-F-20205.courseDescription: An investigation of the relationship between human beings and their natural and built environments. This interdisciplinary course will draw from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities to explore major social, cultural, economic, regulatory, ethical, ecological and technological aspects of environmental issues.
ENV100H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
ENV100H1F will be conducted entirely online. Lectures and tutorials will be conducted asynchronously.
Each noon on the day of the regularly scheduled class (Tuesday and Thursday), the recorded lecture will be made available on Quercus in video format, complete with slides. Students will be asked to send questions between lectures via email, and their questions will be addressed in subsequent lectures.
Tutorials will be led by TAs, and tutorials will consist of a mixture of online chat rooms, email inquiries, videoed how-to sessions.
Students will be required to submit essay-type assignments via Turnitin.

ENV100H1-S-20205.courseDescription: An investigation of the relationship between human beings and their natural and built environments. This interdisciplinary course will draw from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities to explore major social, cultural, economic, regulatory, ethical, ecological and technological aspects of environmental issues.
ENV100H1-S-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
ENV100H1S will be conducted entirely online. 

Lectures will be conducted asynchronously, and tutorials will be conducted synchronously. 

Each noon on the day of what was the regularly scheduled class (Tuesday and Thursday), the recorded lecture will be made available on Quercus in video format, complete with slides. Students will be asked to send questions between lectures via email, and their questions will be addressed in subsequent lectures. 

Tutorials will be led by TAs, and tutorials will be optional synchronous tutorial sessions through Blackboard Collaborate, which will be recorded and available for individual viewing, and will be offered to help students prepare for assignments. 

Students will be required to submit essay-type assignments, including a final assessment during the final assessment period, via Turnitin.
ENV100H1-S-20205.deliveryInstructions:
ENV100H1S will be conducted entirely online. 

Lectures will be conducted asynchronously, and tutorials will be conducted synchronously. 

Each noon on the day of what was the regularly scheduled class (Tuesday and Thursday), the recorded lecture will be made available on Quercus in video format, complete with slides. Students will be asked to send questions between lectures via email, and their questions will be addressed in subsequent lectures. 

Tutorials will be led by TAs, and tutorials will be optional synchronous tutorial sessions through Blackboard Collaborate, which will be recorded and available for individual viewing, and will be offered to help students prepare for assignments. 

Students will be required to submit essay-type assignments, including a final assessment during the final assessment period, via Turnitin.

ENV200H1-F-20205.courseTitle: Assessing Global Change: Science and the Environment
ENV200H1-F-20205.courseDescription: The perspective which scientists bring to the understanding and resolution of environmental concerns having global implications: atmospheric systems and climate change, the biosphere and conservation of biodiversity. This living things and their environment breadth course is intended to fulfill the environmental literacy requirement for students in the BA programs of the School of the Environment or the living things and their environment breadth course requirement for Commerce, Humanities and Social Science students
ENV200H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
This course is registered as a hybrid course.
The lectures, tutorials, assignments and final exam are asynchronous.
The only component that makes this course synchronous is the mid-term test. You will log on to Quercus during a specific time to take the mid-term test.

ENV200H1-S-20205.courseTitle: Assessing Global Change: Science and the Environment
ENV200H1-S-20205.courseDescription: The perspective which scientists bring to the understanding and resolution of environmental concerns having global implications: atmospheric systems and climate change, the biosphere and conservation of biodiversity. This living things and their environment breadth course is intended to fulfill the environmental literacy requirement for students in the BA programs of the School of the Environment or the living things and their environment breadth course requirement for Commerce, Humanities and Social Science students
ENV200H1-S-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
This course is registered as a hybrid course. 
The lectures, tutorials, assignments and final exam are asynchronous. 
The only component that makes this course synchronous is the mid-term test. You will log on to Quercus during a specific time to take the mid-term test.

ENV221H1-S-20205.courseDescription: One of two foundation courses for the School’s undergraduate program. Introduces students to ways in which different disciplines contribute to our understanding of environment. Instructors and guest lecturers are drawn from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities and will present subject matter, assumptions, conceptualizations and methodologies of their disciplines.
ENV221H1-S-20205.webTimetableInstructions:
This is an online hybrid course. 
Lectures will be delivered live during the regularly scheduled lecture hours (Mondays and Wednesdays, 2 – 4 pm, EST) via Blackboard Collaborate, and every attempt will be made to record them for later (re)viewing. Power point presentations will be uploaded in batches, but class discussions will not be recorded. 
There will be three writing assignments and up to five synchronous tutorials. Students will be expected to upload their papers in word format onto Quercus.

ENV492H1-F-20205.courseDescription: A research project or selected topic in an area of environment not otherwise available in the Faculty, meant to develop skills in independent study of interdisciplinary topics. A written proposal co-signed by the student and supervisor must be submitted for approval by the Academic Associate Director of the School normally one month prior to commencing the course. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
ENV492H1-F-20205.prerequisite: Completion of 14.0 FCE including ENV221H1/ENV222H1, and enrolment in a School of the Environment program
ENV492H1-F-20205.webTimetableInstructions: Students can download the application form and course outline by going to https://www.environment.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/course-list/ and clicking on the "Syllabus" link for ENV492H or ENV493H. For more information, please contact David Powell at david.powell@utoronto.ca.
